item.title: Reputation scoring for open source contributors: what reputer measures and why
item.description: Every dependency you install, every pull request you merge, carries an implicit trust decision. You trust that the person behind the commit is who they claim to be, that their account hasn’t been compromised, and that their contribution is genuine. Most of the time, that trust is warranted. But supply chain attacks like the xz utils backdoor remind us that trust without verification is a vulnerability.

item.title: Software supply chain data fatigue and what I’ve learned from SBOM, vulnerability reports
item.description: If you are doing any vulnerability detection in your software release pipeline today, you are already familiar with the volumes of data these scanners can generate. That dataset gets significantly larger when you add things like license scanning and Software Bill of Materials (SBOM) generation. That volume of data gets further compounded with each highly-automated pipeline you operate. This can quickly lead to what I refer to as a Software Supply Chain Security (S3C) data fatigue, as many vulnerabilities you’ll discover you simply can’t do anything about. There is an actionable signal in there actually, it’s just hard to find it in the midst of all the noise.
